custodyTypes.name: Multi-Institution Custody
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Bitcoin keys and assets distributed across multiple independent regulated custodians, eliminating single points of failure.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Multi-institution custody distributes your Bitcoin across multiple independent, regulated custodians rather than trusting a single entity. If one custodian is compromised, hacked, or fails, your assets remain safe with the others. This model emerged after high-profile failures like FTX and Celsius demonstrated the catastrophic risk of single-custodian dependence.
pros: No single entity can freeze all assets
cons: May have higher all-in fees than single custodian

custodyTypes.name: Self-Custody / Multisig
custodyTypes.shortDescription: You hold your own private keys using hardware wallets and multisignature setups. Maximum sovereignty, maximum responsibility.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Self-custody means you control your own private keys — 'not your keys, not your coins.' Modern self-custody solutions use multisignature (multisig) technology where multiple keys are required to move funds, reducing the risk of single key loss. Collaborative custody models add a trusted third party who holds one key as a backup.
cons: You are solely responsible for security

custodyTypes.name: Exchange Custody
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Bitcoin held on a cryptocurrency exchange. Convenient for trading but introduces significant counterparty risk.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Exchange custody is the most common form — you buy Bitcoin on an exchange and leave it there. The exchange controls your private keys. This is convenient for active traders but introduces counterparty risk: if the exchange is hacked, goes bankrupt, or freezes withdrawals, you may lose access to your funds. FTX, Mt. Gox, and Celsius are cautionary examples.
bestFor: Beginners who plan to self-custody later

custodyTypes.name: Qualified Custodian
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Regulated financial institutions that meet SEC and state requirements for safeguarding client assets, including digital assets.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Qualified custodians are regulated financial institutions meeting specific legal requirements for safeguarding client assets. In the US, the SEC requires registered investment advisers to use qualified custodians. These institutions demonstrate robust security controls, adequate capitalization, and regulatory compliance. They serve as the institutional-grade single-custodian option.

custodyTypes.name: Cold Storage / Hardware
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Bitcoin stored on hardware devices disconnected from the internet. Air-gapped security for long-term holdings.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Cold storage keeps your Bitcoin's private keys on devices that never connect to the internet, making them immune to remote hacking. Hardware wallets like Ledger and Trezor are the most common consumer cold storage solutions. Institutional cold storage uses HSMs (Hardware Security Modules) in secure facilities.
cons: No recovery if seed phrase lost

custodyTypes.name: Collaborative Custody
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Multisig setup where you hold some keys while a trusted provider holds others. Combines self-custody sovereignty with professional backup.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Collaborative custody uses multisignature technology where keys are split between you and a service provider. Typically in a 2-of-3 setup: you hold 2 keys, the provider holds 1. You can always move funds independently, but the provider can assist with recovery if you lose a key. This bridges the gap between full self-custody and third-party custody.
bestFor: HNW individuals who want control + safety net
Self-custody users who want professional backup
pros: You maintain control (hold majority of keys)
No single entity can move your funds
cons: Provider still has some key access
Still relies on one provider for the backup key
Fewer options than pure custodial solutions

custodyTypes.name: ETF / Indirect Exposure
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Gain Bitcoin exposure through regulated exchange-traded funds without directly holding cryptocurrency.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Bitcoin ETFs allow investors to gain exposure to Bitcoin's price movements through traditional brokerage accounts. The ETF issuer purchases and custodies actual Bitcoin, while investors hold shares of the fund. This eliminates the need for crypto wallets, private keys, or direct custody concerns. Ideal for retirement accounts (IRAs, 401ks) and traditional investors who want Bitcoin allocation within existing portfolios.
pros: No crypto wallet or key management needed
cons: Dependent on ETF issuer and custodian

custodyTypes.name: Technology Provider
custodyTypes.shortDescription: Companies providing custody infrastructure and technology to institutions rather than direct custody services to end users.
custodyTypes.longDescription: Technology providers build the custody infrastructure that banks, exchanges, and financial institutions use to safeguard digital assets. They provide MPC (Multi-Party Computation) key management, governance frameworks, HSMs, and policy engines. While they don't directly custody assets, their technology underpins much of the institutional crypto custody ecosystem.
